sn35.247:1.5: Manu 9.256–260 describes various “thorns” (i.e. “pests”) as thieves, etc. Kauṭilya’s Arthaśāstra devotes the entirety of book 4 to removing thorns to the realm.
sn35.247:3.1: Each of the six animals is connected to the corresponding sense in some way.
sn35.247:3.2: Ahi (“snake”) puns with akkhi (“eye”). Also, the cobra is famed for the false eyes on its hood.
sn35.247:3.3: Susumāra (literally “child-killer”) may be either the Gangetic dolphin (MN 129:21.3) or the crocodile (Cp 27:1.3). Here it is probably the dolphin, which has residual eyesight and primarily relies on echolocation. This association may be reinforced by the blowhole appearing like a prominent ear.
sn35.247:3.4: A bird is notable for its beaked “nose”.
sn35.247:3.5: Dogs are notoriously ravenous, thus standing for the tongue.
sn35.247:3.10: The termite mound is said to be the body (MN 23:4.1), to which the eye is attracted. | The dolphin follows its ear. | The bird flies to the sky like someone sniffing the air. | The dog goes to the village where the food is. | The jackal feeds on discarded bodies. | The monkey leaps from branch to branch in the jungle (SN 12.61:4.2).
